title: Fabio Rossitto
text:
Fabio Rossitto (; born 21 September 1971) is an Italian <a href="Association%20football">football</a> manager and a former player who played as a <a href="midfielder">midfielder</a> from 1989 to 2007.
Club career.
Born in <a href="Aviano">Aviano</a>, <a href="Province%20of%20Pordenone">Province of Pordenone</a>, Rossitto's career saw him play for a number of Italian and one foreign club during his eighteen-year spell as a player. He began his career with <a href="Udinese%20Calcio">Udinese</a> (1989–1997 and 2002–2004), where he spent a large part of his career, becoming an import part of the side. He later moved to <a href="S.S.C.%20Napoli">Napoli</a> (1997–1999), <a href="ACF%20Fiorentina">Fiorentina</a> (1999–2002), <a href="K.F.C.%20Germinal%20Beerschot">Germinal Beerschot</a> (2004), <a href="F.B.C.%20Unione%20Venezia">Venezia</a> (2005), and <a href="Sacilese%20Calcio">Sacilese</a> (2005–07), where he ended his career. During his time with Fiorentina, he won the <a href="2000%E2%80%9301%20Coppa%20Italia">Coppa Italia</a> of 2001. Fiorentina paid 15 billion <a href="Italian%20lira">lire</a> to sign Rossitto (€7.75 million) as well as another 5 billion for half of the registration rights of <a href="Giuseppe%20Taglialatela">Giuseppe Taglialatela</a>. in the same window, Napoli signed <a href="Emiliano%20Bigica">Emiliano Bigica</a> from Fiorentina.
International career.
Rossito represented Italy at <a href="Italy%20national%20under-21%20football%20team">Under-21 level</a> on nine occasions and was part of the team that won the <a href="1994%20UEFA%20European%20Under-21%20Championship">1994 UEFA European Under-21 Championship</a> in France under the management of <a href="Cesare%20Maldini">Cesare Maldini</a>, for the first time in Italy's history. All of his appearances at Under-21 level came in 1994.
Rossitto had one appearance for the senior <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team">Italy national football team</a>, coming on as a substitute in a 2–0 away win over Hungary on 1 June 1996. He was part of Italy's squad at the <a href="1996%20UEFA%20European%20Championship">1996 UEFA European Championship</a> in England.
Managerial career.
From January 2013 to the end of the season Rossitto served as head coach of <a href="Pordenone%20Calcio">Pordenone</a> in the <a href="Serie%20D">Serie D</a>.
In the 2013–14 season he was the coach of <a href="Unione%20Triestina%202012%20S.S.D.">Triestina</a>.
In November 2014, he agreed a comeback at <a href="Pordenone%20Calcio">Pordenone</a>, then bottom-placed in the <a href="Lega%20Pro">Lega Pro</a>. After failing to save the team from relegation, he left Pordenone by the end of the season. In January 2016, he was then hired as new head coach of Lega Pro club <a href="U.S.%20Cremonese">Cremonese</a>, leading the club till the end of the season.
In April 2017, he agreed to accept an offer to serve as <a href="Diego%20Bortoluzzi">Diego Bortoluzzi</a>'s assistant at Serie A strugglers <a href="U.S.%20Citt%C3%A0%20di%20Palermo">Palermo</a> till the end of the season.
On 15 February 2018, he once again returned to <a href="Pordenone%20Calcio">Pordenone</a> in the <a href="Serie%20C">Serie C</a> until the end of the season.
Honours.
Fiorentina
